entry.title: Article-Investors brace for a painful crash into America’s debt-ceiling-2023-05-15
entry.content:
Finance & economics | Buttonwood
Investors brace for a painful crash into America’s debt-ceiling
A solution will probably be found. But default is no longer unthinkable
May 10th 2023
Most of the time, the impossibility of America defaulting on its sovereignbonds is taken as a fundamental axiom of the financial system. The countryissues the world’s reserve currency, so investors always stand ready to lendit money. And if you are able to borrow more, you can pay back your debts.
Yet Washington is once again reminding the world that, through sheermulishness, a default is indeed possible. Every now and again—as in 2011, 2013and today—America smacks into its “debt ceiling”, a political device thatplaces a hard limit (currently $31.4trn, or 117% of gdp) on gross governmentborrowing. Congress must then agree to raise or waive the ceiling in order toprevent the Treasury from failing to make bond payments or meet spendingobligations. This time Janet Yellen, the treasury secretary, has warned thatthe government may run out of cash and accounting manoeuvres as soon as June1st. And so on May 9th, congressional leaders gathered in the Oval Office withPresident Joe Biden for the very first stage of negotiation. They are a longway from a deal.
The stage is thus set for a game of brinkmanship in which a Republican-controlled House of Representatives tries to wring concessions from Mr Biden,as the nation’s creditworthiness hangs in the balance. The two sides shouldfind a way to avoid catastrophe. But as Washington’s staring contestintensifies, Wall Street’s finest are less inclined to get involved. Themerest hint of a default has already set traders to work looking for ways toprotect their investments.
To understand why, consider what a default would mean. Short-term Treasuries,or “t-bills”, are the closest thing there is to a risk-free asset. This makesthem a favourite of corporate cash managers (who want an ultra-safe return)and any trader needing to post collateral (which must hold its value and beeasy to sell). If the government stiffs corporate treasurers, companies willmiss payments to one another and the wheels of commerce will grind to anagonising halt. Make traders’ collateral vanish, and financial contracts ofall stripes will start to fall apart, unleashing chaos in global markets.
Small wonder, then, that investors are rushing to protect themselves. Aclamour for t-bills maturing before any possible default has given rise towild swings in the yield of the world’s safest asset. One-month bills yielded4.7% at the start of April. Over the next three weeks that fell to 3.4%, evenas the Federal Reserve prepared to raise its interest rate to 5-5.25%. Butone-month bills now mature after June 1st, when the Treasury might haveexhausted its cash. And so demand has cratered, with their yield soaring bymore than two percentage points in a matter of weeks. One trading bossdescribes having her team attempt to manually override their settlementsoftware, to ensure that bills which mature without being paid do not simplyvanish from the system.
Longer-term Treasuries have so far seemed safer, under the assumption that anactual default would shock politicians out of their stubbornness, and would bequickly rectified. Yet even they are not immune. The cost of insuring five-year Treasuries against default, once the very definition of throwing awaymoney, has quadrupled over the past 12 months (a fact admittedly explained inpart by the market’s lack of liquidity).
What next? For investors who think there is no chance of Washington careeningover the precipice, it is time to snap up t-bills at a discount and sellpointless bond insurance to the nervous. But even optimists have cause forconcern. Since the Treasury would have run down its cash reserves to virtuallynothing, a deal would be followed by a glut of issuance to rebuild the buffer.Even the best-case scenario would drain liquidity from the market and may pushyields higher.
The stockmarket, meanwhile, looks shaky either way. Analysts at pimco, anasset manager, note that over the past dozen years, the s&p 500 index hasfallen by an average of 6.5% in the month running up to a debt-ceilingdeadline—even though these have always been met. Under a default it would faremuch worse. In 2013, during a previous debt-ceiling stand-off, Fed officialssimulated the effects of a month-long default. They estimated that stockprices would fall by 30% and the dollar by 10%.
In the meantime, expect traders to get even more jittery. America’s politicswill prevent an early deal, and it could well take the markets freaking out toforce one at all. Default remains the least likely outcome. But as investorsare acutely aware, it is no longer unthinkable.

entry.title: The world in brief 2023-05-15
entry.content:
The world in brief

Catch up quickly on the global stories that matter

Turks voted in their country’s presidential election. Polls had suggested thatthe increasingly autocratic president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, could lose toKemal Kilicdaroglu, who represents an alliance of parties. Both sides claimedto be in the lead, but with around 90% of the votes counted neither candidatelooked likely to reach the 50% threshold required to avoid a run-off laterthis month.

土耳其人参加了本国的总统选举。民调表明，越来越独裁的总统雷杰普·塔伊普·埃尔多安可能会输给代表联盟党派的凯马尔·基利奇达罗卢。双方都声称自己领先，但是在大约90%的选票计算出来后，两位候选人都不太可能达到必须要避免本月晚些时候进行第二轮投票的50%门槛。

Volodymyr Zelensky arrived in Germany , his first visit to thecountry since the Russian invasion of his country began. In a meeting with thechancellor, Olaf Scholz, Ukraine’s president thanked Germany for being a “truefriend”, and said that with more Western support a Russian defeat would be“irreversible”. The German government announced €2.7bn ($2.95bn) of militaryaid for Ukraine ahead of his arrival. Earlier, Mr Zelensky met Italy’sprime minister, Giorgia Meloni, in Rome. Despite some members of her right-wing coalition having expressed pro-Kremlin views, Ms Meloni has pledged hergovernment’s support for Ukraine.

弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基首次访问德国，自俄罗斯入侵乌克兰以来。在与总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨的会晤中，乌克兰总统感谢德国作为“真正的朋友”，并表示通过更多的西方支持，俄罗斯的失败将是“不可逆转的”。德国政府在他抵达之前宣布向乌克兰提供27亿欧元（29.5亿美元）的军事援助。此前，泽连斯基在罗马会见了意大利总理乔尔吉娅·梅洛尼。尽管她的右翼联盟中有些成员表达了亲克里姆林宫的观点，但梅洛尼承诺支持乌克兰。

Voters in Thailand’s general election voters emphatically rejected themilitary-backed government. Young people in particular turned away from theprime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha, a former general who seized power in a coupin 2014. His leadership has been defined by economic incompetence andcorruption. The two largest parties, Move Forward and Pheu Thai, will probablyenter coalition talks in the coming weeks, though the military establishmentmay not cede power graciously.

泰国大选选民强烈反对得到军方支持的政府。特别是年轻人背离了总理巴育·占奥差，他是一位在2014年政变中夺权的前将军。他的领导以经济无能和腐败为特征。两个最大的政党，“前进党”和“泰赛党”，可能会在未来几周进入联合谈判，尽管军方机构可能不会慷慨地放弃权力。

“Emphatically” means forcefully or strongly. In this context, it indicates that the voters in Thailand’s general election strongly rejected the military-backed government.

Cyclone Mocha hit the coasts of Bangladesh and Myanmar. Windsgusting at 215km per hour and storm surges almost 4 metres higher than thenormal tide are expected. In Bangladesh almost 500,000 people have alreadybeen evacuated to safer areas. The low-lying area of Cox’s Bazar, home to 1mRohingya refugees from Myanmar, is particularly vulnerable.

“莫卡”强台风袭击了孟加拉国和缅甸的海岸。预计风速将达到每小时215公里，风暴潮比正常潮汐高出近4米。在孟加拉国，已有近50万人被疏散到安全地区。科克斯巴扎尔地区是低洼地区，目前居住着来自缅甸的100万罗兴亚难民，特别容易受到影响。

Further heavy fighting was reported in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum,even though both sides–the army and the Rapid Support Forces, a militia–agreedon Thursday to a “declaration of principles” to protect civilians and securehumanitarian access. The Darfur Bar Association reported that more than 100people had been killed in fighting in the western region of Darfur on Fridayand Saturday.

尽管双方——军队和民兵组织“快速支援部队”已于周四同意签署一份“原则宣言”以保护平民并确保人道主义援助，但据报道在苏丹首都喀土穆仍然发生了激烈的战斗。达尔富尔律师协会报告称，在周五和周六的战斗中，达尔富尔地区已有100多人被杀。

The new boss of Twitter spoke publicly for the first time since takingcharge of the social-media platform on Friday. In a tweet Linda Yaccarino saidthat she had been inspired by the vision of Elon Musk, Twitter’s owner, to“transform” the company. Twitter has suffered a big loss of advertisingrevenue since Mr Musk bought the business for $44bn last year.

自上周五接管这个社交媒体平台以来，Twitter的新老板首次公开发言。在一条推文中，琳达·雅卡里诺表示，她受到了Twitter所有者埃隆·马斯克的愿景的启发，希望“改造”公司。自马斯克去年以440亿美元收购该业务以来，Twitter已经遭受了巨大的广告收入损失。

所有者（Owner）通常指拥有公司或组织全部或大部分股份和财产的个人或实体。而老板（Boss）则指某个公司、组织或团队的领导者或管理者，可能是雇主或经理人等。通常情况下，老板是公司的高管或高级管理人员，他们管理公司的运营和业务，以便实现公司的目标。因此，所有者通常也可以是老板；但是，在某些情况下，公司的所有者可能并不是公司的实际经营者或老板。

Sweden won the Eurovision Song Contest , a staggeringly popularcheesefest. Loreen sang the winning entry, “Tattoo”, the second time she hastriumphed at the competition. Sweden has now prevailed in the annual contest arecord-equalling seven times. Its first success came in 1974 with a then-obscure band named ABBA.

瑞典赢得了备受欢迎的“欧洲歌唱大赛”，这是一项盛行的奶酪音乐比赛。Loreen演唱了获胜的参赛作品“Tattoo”，这是她第二次在比赛中获胜。瑞典现在已经创下了七次获胜的纪录。它的首次胜利是在1974年，当时一支名为ABBA的不知名乐队获胜。

“Staggeringly” means extremely or astonishingly, beyond what might be considered normal or expected. In this context, it indicates that the Eurovision Song Contest is an enormously popular event.

The president says “Choose France”

Photo:Reuters

Emmanuel Macron will host a summit in Versailles on Monday for more than 200world business leaders to encourage them to invest in his country. Newprojects worth €13bn ($14bn) will be announced.The event comes at a time whenthe president is making a push for a new industrial policy, to curb dependenceon long supply chains and accelerate the green transition, both at home and inEurope.

On Thursday he called for France to stop subsidising the purchase of electriccars made outside Europe, in response to massive state support for the sectorin both America and China. On the next day Mr Macron visited the port city ofDunkirk, where ProLogium, a Taiwanese firm, is building a €5.2bn electric-battery factory–just the sort of new investment he is after. This focus onfactories and jobs is good for France. But it’s also a way for Mr Macron tomove the national conversation on after months of protests against his pensionreform.

埃马纽埃尔·马克龙将于周一在凡尔赛主持一个峰会，与200多名世界商界领袖会面，鼓励他们在法国投资。将宣布价值130亿欧元（140亿美元）的新项目。这次活动正值总统推动新的工业政策之际，旨在减少对长供应链的依赖，加速绿色转型，不仅在本国而且在欧洲范围内。

星期四，他呼吁法国停止补贴购买在欧洲以外生产的电动汽车，作为对美国和中国在该领域提供大规模国家支持的回应。第二天，马克龙先生访问了敦刻尔克港口城市，在那里台湾公司ProLogium正在建造一家52亿欧元的电池工厂，这正是他所追求的新投资类型。这种专注于工厂和就业的重点对法国有好处。但对马克龙来说，这也是一种方式，可以在数月的抗议反对他的养老金改革之后，推动国家对话的进程。

Sudan’s agony is set to continue

Photo:Rex Shutterstock

Peace talks to end Sudan’s month-long civil war resumed on Sunday in SaudiArabia. Few expect them to succeed. After weeks of fighting for control of thecapital, Khartoum, neither the Sudanese Armed Forces, the national army, northe Rapid Support Forces, a paramilitary group led by Muhammad Hamdan Dagalo(a warlord known as Hemedti), has gained a decisive advantage. And neither islikely to back down just yet.

So the misery of Sudan’s civilians is set to continue. More than 750 peoplehave already been killed, and more than 200,000 have fled to neighbouringcountries. In Khartoum RSF troops have dug themselves into residentialdistricts while the SAF’s fighter jets pummel them from the sky. Four days oftalks in Jeddah last week produced only a “declaration of principles” for thearmies to follow, such as allowing aid to reach civilians. But as both sidescontinue to deploy more troops to the capital, even this modest agreement willbecome ever harder to implement.

周日在沙特阿拉伯恢复了结束苏丹长达一个月的内战的和平谈判。很少有人认为这些谈判会成功。经过数周在首都喀土穆控制权的争夺之后，苏丹武装部队、国家军队和由穆罕默德·哈姆丹·达加洛（一个被称为海梅迪的军阀）领导的准军事组织“快速支援部队”都没有获得明显的优势。而且双方都不可能立即让步。

因此，苏丹民众的痛苦还将继续。已有超过750人死亡，超过20万人逃往邻国。在喀土穆，快速支援部队的部队已经挖掘到居民区，而苏丹武装部队的战斗机则从天空中轰击他们。上周在吉达进行的四天谈判仅仅产生了一份“原则宣言”，要求军队允许援助物资到达平民。但是，随着双方继续向首都调动更多军队，即使是这种温和的协议也将变得越来越难以实施。

A new Martin Luther King biography

Photo:Alamy

The reverence with which Americans of all political stripes regard MartinLuther King today obscures how divisive and unpopular he was in his time.Patriotic but unsparing in his criticism of America, struggling to balancefaith in his countrymen with growing pessimism about his country’s ability toovercome its demons, he was a thorny and demanding thinker and activist.Jonathan Eig’s magnificent new biography, “King: A Life”, is a welcome effortto wrestle with him in all of his complexity.

Using a combination of political shrewdness, moral suasion and physicalcourage, he led the most successful pressure campaign in American history,inspiring sweeping federal laws that banned discrimination in publicaccommodation, voting and housing. The last came in 1968, just a week after abullet ended his life. For King, ending segregation was not his movement’s endbut its beginning: he sought brotherhood and equality. Those goals arefiendishly difficult to achieve through policy, but still worth striving for.

今天，美国各个政治派别对马丁·路德·金的尊敬掩盖了他在当时的分裂和不受欢迎之处。他是一个爱国者，但对美国进行了不留情面的批评，努力平衡对同胞的信任与对国家战胜内部魔鬼能力的日益悲观，他是一个棘手而苛刻的思想家和活动家。乔纳森·艾格的新传记《金：一生》运用政治机敏、道德说服和勇气，领导了美国历史上最成功的压力运动，促成了全国范围内禁止公共场所、选举和住房歧视的广泛联邦法律。最后一项于1968年通过，仅仅一周后，一颗子弹结束了他的生命。对于金来说，结束种族隔离并不是运动的终点，而是起点：他寻求兄弟般的团结和平等。这些目标通过政策极其难以实现，但仍值得为之奋斗。

Daily Quiz

Our baristas will serve you a new question each day this week. On Friday yourchallenge is to give us all five answers and, as important, tell us theconnecting theme. Email your responses (and include mention of your home cityand country) by 1700 GMT on Friday to QuizEspresso@economist.com. We’ll p’ickrandomly from those with the right answers and crown three winners onSaturday.

Monday : Which stretch of water between the Malay peninsula and Sumatrais the main shipping lane between the Indian and Pacific oceans?

我们的咖啡师将在本周每天为您提供一个新问题。在周五，您要面临的挑战是给出所有五个答案，并告诉我们连接主题的重要性。请在格林威治标准时间周五下午5点之前通过电子邮件QuizEspresso@economist.com发送您的答案（并注明您的家乡城市和国家）。我们将从正确答案中随机选择三名获胜者，并于周六宣布结果。

周一：连接马来半岛和苏门答腊的哪个水域是印度洋和太平洋之间的主要航运通道？答案是麻六甲海峡（Strait of Malacca）。

We turn not older with years, but newer every day

Emily Dickinson

entry.title: Article-Just how good can China get at generative AI?-2023-05-14
entry.content:
Just how good can China get at generative AI?
Its models may in time rival America’s. But that may not translate into an economic or military edge
May 9th 2023
这篇文章讨论了中美在技术领域，尤其是人工智能（AI）方面的竞争。虽然中国在某些衡量AI技术水平的指标上领先于美国，例如高度引用的AI论文数量，但它在建立基础模型方面落后于美国，而这些基础模型为生成型AI提供了能力。这是由于数据、硬件和专业知识的短缺，部分原因是美国对关键技术的出口管制。尽管中国正在努力解决其中一些挑战，但它可能难以充分利用生成型AI。最终，文章认为，无论是美国还是中国，都不太可能在AI建模方面建立不可逾越的领先地位，但美国可能在将尖端创新传播到整个经济中具有优势。本文仅供用来英语学习，观点仅供参考，在编辑时，编者已删除部分不和谐的内容。
IF YOU LISTEN to the bombast in Beijing and Washington, America and China areengaged in an all-out contest for technological supremacy. “Fundamentally, webelieve that a select few technologies are set to play an outsized importanceover the coming decade,” declared Jake Sullivan, President Joe Biden’snational security adviser, last September. In February ***, China’s*, echoed the sentiment, stating that “we urgently need tostrengthen basic research and solve key technology problems” in order to “copewith international science and technology competition, achieve a high level ofself-reliance and self-improvement”.
如果你倾听北京和华盛顿的夸张言辞，你会发现美国和中国正在全面竞争科技优势。去年9月份，乔·拜登总统的国家安全顾问杰克·沙利文宣布：“基本上，我们认为在未来十年里，只有少数几项技术将发挥超出比例的重要性。” 2月份，***重申这种观点，表示“我们迫切需要加强基础研究，解决关键技术问题”，以此来“应对国际科技竞争，实现更高水平的自力更生和自我提升”。
  1. Bombast: This word refers to language that is pompous, exaggerated, or pretentious. In this context, it refers to the exaggerated and grandiose claims made by leaders of both China and the United States regarding their countries’ technological capabilities.
  2. Technological supremacy: This phrase refers to the concept of one country being superior to others in terms of technological advancement, innovation, and dominance.
  3. “all-out” 是一个形容词短语，表示全力以赴、毫不保留地、尽一切可能的意思。在文中的上下文中，“all-out contest” 指的是中美两国之间在技术方面展开的激烈竞争，双方都在极力争取领先地位，并且投入了所有资源和能力。
  4. “a select few” 是一个短语，表示一些特定的人或事物中的选出来的少数精英。在文中的上下文中，“a select few technologies” 意思是指挑选出来的那些技术，这些技术被认为对于未来的发展和进步尤为重要。这些技术可能是高度先进、能够带来实质性成果、能够推动行业发展的关键技术。
  5. National security adviser: This term refers to a high-ranking government official who advises the president or other top officials on matters relating to national security.
  6. “Sentiment” 是一个名词，表示情感、态度或观点等。在文中的上下文中，“echoed the sentiment” 意思是指***发表讲话时表达了与美国国家安全顾问杰克·沙利文相似的观点或态度，即强调技术研究和基础研究的重要性，并强调要应对国际科学技术竞争的挑战，实现科技自立和自我提升的目标。
  7. Basic research: This refers to scientific research that seeks to expand knowledge and understanding of a particular subject without necessarily having a specific practical application.
  8. Self-reliance: This term refers to the ability of a country or individual to support and sustain themselves without relying on external assistance or resources.
  9. Self-improvement: This term refers to the process of making oneself better or more capable through personal effort and development.
No technology seems to obsess policymakers on both sides of the Pacific moreright now than artificial intelligence (AI). The rapid improvements in theabilities of “generative” AIs like ChatGPT, which analyse the web’s worth ofhuman text, images or sounds and can then create increasingly passablesimulacrums, have only strengthened the obsession. If generative AI proves astransformational as its boosters claim, the technology could give those whowield it an economic and military edge in the 21st century’s chiefgeopolitical contest. Western and Chinese strategists already talk of an AIarms race. Can China win it?
目前，似乎没有任何技术比人工智能（AI）更让太平洋两岸的政策制定者着迷了。像ChatGPT这样“生成式”AI的快速进步，可以分析网络上的大量文本、图像或声音，然后创造出越来越接近真实的模拟品，这只会加强人们对它的痴迷。如果生成式AI证明像支持者所说的那样具有变革性，该技术可能在21世纪主要的地缘政治竞争中给那些运用它的人带来经济和军事优势。西方和中国的战略家已经开始谈论AI军备竞赛。中国能赢得这场竞赛吗？
  1. “worth of” 是一个短语，表示一定数量或价值的某种物品。在句中，“analyse the web’s worth of human text, images or sounds” 表示分析网络上包含了大量的人类文本、图像和声音，其总量或价值是巨大的。也可以换用“amount of”，意思相近，都表示数量或价值。
  2. “create increasingly passable simulacrums” 中的主语是“AIs”，动词是“create”，意为“创造”；“increasingly”则说明这些模拟品变得越来越好，能够越来越逼真地模拟出真实的物体、场景或人物。其中，“passable”表示“可通过”的意思，指生成式AI所创建的模拟品已经足够接近真实，以至于可以欺骗人类感官的检测和判断。而“simulacrums”则表示“模拟品”的意思，指生成式AI所创造出来的能够具有某种特定特征或品质的虚拟对象。
On some measures of AI prowess, the autocracy pulled ahead some time ago (seechart). China surpassed America in the share of highly cited AI papers in2019; in 2021, 26% of AI conference publications globally came from China,compared with America’s share of 17%. Nine of the world’s top teninstitutions, by volume of AI publications, are Chinese. According to onepopular benchmark, so are the top five labs working on computer vision, a typeof AI particularly useful to a***.
从一些衡量人工智能实力的标准来看，中国在某些方面早已领先（见图表）。例如，2019年中国在高被引用人工智能论文的占比上超过了美国；2021年，全球AI会议论文中有26%来自中国，而美国的份额为17%。世界排名前十的机构中，有九个是中国的，这些机构以发表AI论文数量而著名。另外，根据一个流行的基准测试，五个最顶尖的计算机视觉实验室也均位于中国，这种人工智能对于***尤为有用。
Yet when it comes to “foundation models”, which give generative AIs theirwits, America is firmly in front (see charts 2 and 3). ChatGPT and thepioneering model behind it, the latest version of which is called GPT-4, arethe brainchild of OpenAI, an American startup. A handful of other Americanfirms, from small ones such as Anthropic or Stability AI to behemoths likeGoogle, Meta and Microsoft (which part-owns OpenAI), have their own powerfulsystems. ERNIE, a Chinese rival to ChatGPT built by Baidu, China’s internet-search giant, is widely seen as less clever. Alibaba and Tencent, China’smightiest tech titans, have yet to unveil their own generative AIs.
然而，当涉及到给生成式AI赋予智能的“基础模型”时，美国处于明显领先地位（见图表2和3）。ChatGPT及其背后的开创性模型（最新版本称为GPT-4）是美国初创公司OpenAI的杰作。除此之外，一些其他的美国公司，从小型企业如Anthropic或Stability AI到像Google、Meta和Microsoft这样的巨头（其中Microsoft是OpenAI的股东之一），都拥有自己强大的系统。中国搜索巨头百度打造的与ChatGPT竞争的ERNIE被广泛认为没有那么聪明。中国的科技巨头阿里巴巴和腾讯还没有推出自己的生成式AI。
  1. foundation models: 基础模型，指用于训练生成式AI的基本算法和模型结构。这些模型通常需要大量数据和计算资源进行训练，并且对于生成式AI的表现和效果至关重要。
  2. wits: 智能、机智，指生成式AI所具备的理解、分析和创造的能力。
  3. OpenAI: 一个人工智能研究公司，总部位于美国旧金山。该公司致力于研发最先进的人工智能技术，并通过开源软件和研究论文来促进人工智能领域的发展。
  4. Anthropic: 美国一家初创企业，主要从事人工智能和机器学习领域的研究和开发工作。
  5. behemoths: 庞然大物、巨头，是指在某个行业或领域中拥有强大影响力和实力的公司或组织。
  6. ERNIE: 一个由中国搜索引擎巨头百度开发的面向生成式AI领域的基础模型，被视为与ChatGPT竞争的对手之一。
  7. generative AIs: 生成式人工智能，是一种通过分析海量数据并自动生成新的内容和信息的人工智能算法和模型。这种人工智能可以用于自然语言处理、图像生成、音频合成等方面。
  8. “Brainchild” 是一个名词，指的是某个人或团队所创造、发明或提出的想法、计划或设计。在文章中，“brainchild of OpenAI” 指的是由美国初创公司OpenAI研发的生成式AI模型ChatGPT和其背后的基础模型。因为这些模型是由OpenAI的工程师们设计和开发的，所以被称为OpenAI的“brainchild”。
  9. “Brainchild” 是一个名词，指的是某个人或团队所创造、发明或提出的想法、计划或设计。在文章中，“brainchild of OpenAI” 指的是由美国初创公司OpenAI研发的生成式AI模型ChatGPT和其背后的基础模型。因为这些模型是由OpenAI的工程师们设计和开发的，所以被称为OpenAI的“brainchild”。
This leads those in the know to conclude that China is two or three yearsbehind America in building foundation models. There are three reasons for thisunderperformance. The first concerns data. A centralised * should beable to marshal lots of it—the government was, for instance, able to hand overtroves of * information on Chinese citizens to firms such asSenseTime or Megvii that, with the help of China’s leading computer-visionlabs, then used it to develop top-notch facial-recognition systems.
据了解的人得出结论，中国在构建基础模型方面比美国落后了两到三年。这种表现欠佳有三个原因。第一个原因涉及数据。**能够动员大量数据 - 例如，中国政府能够将大量的  *  信息移交给SenseTime或Megvii等公司，然后再利用中国领先的计算机视觉实验室，开发出顶尖的面部识别系统。
  1. in the know: 指知情者或内行人，通常指那些对某个领域、行业或事件有深入了解的人。
  2. foundation models: 基础模型，指用于训练生成式AI的基本算法和模型结构。这些模型通常需要大量数据和计算资源进行训练，并且对于生成式AI的表现和效果至关重要。
  3. underperformance: 表现欠佳，不如预期或不如同类事物的平均水平。
  4. centralised: 集中管理的，指权力、资源、控制等在一个中心集中的状态或情况。与之相对的是分散化的（decentralized）。
  5. marshal: 集合、调动，指将人、资源、资金、信息等有组织地集合、调度和运用起来。
  6. troves: 大量、宝藏，指一大批、大规模的事物或信息。在语境中，它指中国政府向SenseTime或Megvii等公司提供了大量的监视信息，以协助这些公司开发面部识别系统。
  7. computer-vision: 计算机视觉，是一种使用计算机和算法来模拟和实现人类视觉能力的技术和方法，包括图像识别、目标跟踪、立体成像等。
  8. facial-recognition systems: 面部识别系统，是一种基于计算机视觉技术和算法的应用程序，用于从图片或视频中识别出人脸，并将其匹配到相应的身份信息上。
  9. Top-notch通常表示最高品质或卓越，常用来形容非常出色或令人印象深刻的事物。例如，一家顶级餐厅可能拥有美味的食物、无可挑剔的服务和良好的氛围。一位顶尖的运动员可能在自己的运动领域非常有才华和技能。
That advantage has proved less formidable in the context of generative AIs,because foundation models are trained on the voluminous unstructured data ofthe web. American model-builders benefit from the fact that 56% of allwebsites are in English, whereas just 1.5% are written in Chinese, accordingto data from W3Techs, an internet-research site. As Yiqin Fu of StanfordUniversity points out, the Chinese interact with the internet primarilythrough mobile super-apps like WeChat and Weibo. These are “walled gardens”,so much of their content is not indexed on search engines. This makes thatcontent harder for AI models to suck up. Lack of data may explain why Wu Dao2.0, a model unveiled in 2021 by the Beijing Academy of ArtificialIntelligence, a state-backed outfit, failed to make a splash despite itspossibly being computationally more complex than GPT-4.
在生成式人工智能的背景下，这种优势在一定程度上没有那么强大，因为基础模型是在互联网上庞大的非结构化数据上进行训练的。根据互联网研究网站W3Techs的数据，美国的模型构建者受益于56%的网站都是用英语编写的，而只有1.5%的网站是用中文编写的。正如斯坦福大学的Yiqin Fu指出的那样，中国人主要通过微信和微博等移动超级应用程序与互联网互动。这些应用程序是“封闭的花园”，因此它们的很多内容没有被搜索引擎索引。这使得该内容对于AI模型来说更难吸收。缺乏数据可能可以解释为什么中国国家支持的北京人工智能科学院在2021年推出了计算复杂性可能比GPT-4更高的Wu Dao 2.0模型，但却没有引起轰动。
  1. formidable: 强大的，令人敬畏的
  2. generative AIs: 生成式人工智能，指那些可以自动生成数据、文本、图像等内容的人工智能。
  3. foundation models: 基础模型，指用于训练生成式AI的基本算法和模型结构。 
  4. unstructured data: 非结构化数据，指没有预先定义好的数据模型或组织方式的数据，如文本、音频和视频等。
  5. W3Techs: 一个互联网研究网站。
  6. walled gardens: 封闭的花园，指类似于社交媒体应用程序等只允许在自己平台内部进行交流和分享的闭环生态系统。
  7. computationally: 计算上的，指与计算机处理相关的事物，如算法复杂度、运行速度等。 
  8. state-backed outfit: 国有机构，指由政府支持或控制的组织或企业。
The second reason for China’s lacklustre generative achievements has to dowith hardware. Last year America imposed export controls on technology thatmight give China a leg-up in AI. These cover the powerful microprocessors usedin the cloud-computing data centres where foundation models do their learning,and the chipmaking tools that could enable China to build such semiconductorson its own.
中国在生成式人工智能方面成就欠佳的第二个原因与硬件有关。去年，美国对可能帮助中国在人工智能领域取得优势的技术实施了出口管制。这些技术包括用于云计算数据中心的强大微处理器，基础模型进行学习的场所以及可能使中国自行生产这种半导体的芯片制造工具。
  1. lacklustre: 意为”平淡无奇的、乏味的”，用于描述缺乏兴趣或激情的事物。
  2. generative: 意为”生成式的”，指的是通过对数据进行分析和学习来生成新的数据或内容的技术。
  3. export controls: 出口管制，指政府采取的限制某些敏感产品或技术出口的措施。
  4. microprocessors：微处理器，是一种集成电路，包含处理器核心和其他必要的组件，可执行计算机程序。
  5. cloud-computing: 云计算，是一种基于互联网的计算方式，将共享的计算资源和数据提供给多个设备。
  6. data centres: 数据中心，是一个集中的网络架构，用于存储、管理和传输大量的数据。
  7. chipmaking tools: 芯片制造工具，是指用于生产半导体芯片的设备和工具。
  8. semiconductors: 半导体，是指在电学特性上介于导体和绝缘体之间，可用于制造各种电子元件。
That hurt Chinese model-builders. An analysis of 26 big Chinese models by theCentre for the Governance of AI, a British think-tank, found that more thanhalf depended on Nvidia, an American chip designer, for their processingpower. Some reports suggest that SMIC, China’s biggest chipmaker, has producedprototypes just a generation or two behind TSMC, the Taiwanese industry leaderthat manufactures chips for Nvidia (see chart 4). But SMIC can probably mass-produce only chips which TSMC was churning out by the million three or fouryears ago.
Chinese AI firms are having trouble getting their hands on another Americanexport: know-how. America remains a magnet for the world’s tech talent; two-thirds of AI experts in America who present papers at the main AI conferenceare foreign-born. Chinese engineers made up 27% of that select group in 2019.Many Chinese AI boffins studied or worked in America before bringing expertiseback home. The covid-19 pandemic and rising Sino-American tensions are causingtheir numbers to dwindle. In the first half of 2022 America granted half asmany visas to Chinese students as in the same period in 2019.
这对中国的模型构建者造成了困扰。英国智库“人工智能治理中心”对26个重要的中国模型进行的分析发现，超过一半的模型依赖于美国芯片设计公司Nvidia的处理能力。一些报告表明，中国最大的芯片制造商中芯国际有可能已经生产出比TSMC（为Nvidia制造芯片的台湾产业领袖）还落后一两代的原型机（见图4）。但是中芯国际很可能只能批量生产三四年前由TSMC生产的那些芯片。
中国的人工智能公司正在面临获取另一种美国出口的技术：专业知识的困境。美国仍然吸引着全球的科技人才；在美国主要的人工智能会议上发表论文的AI专家中，有三分之二来自外国。2019年，中国工程师占据了该精选群体的27%。许多中国人工智能专家在去美国学习或工作后将专业知识带回了祖国。新冠疫情和中美紧张局势导致这些数字逐渐减少。2022年上半年，美国向中国学生授予的签证数量只有2019年同期的一半。
  1. model-builders: 模型构建者，指的是负责开发、建立和调整人工智能模型的专业人士。
  2. Centre for the Governance of AI: 人工智能治理中心，是英国的一个智库，致力于研究人工智能技术的应用和影响。
  3. Nvidia: 美国芯片设计公司，主要生产面向游戏、人工智能和数据中心等领域的高性能处理器和显卡。
  4. processing power: 处理能力，指计算机或其他电子设备执行各种操作的能力。
  5. SMIC: 中芯国际，是中国大陆最大的芯片制造商之一。
  6. TSMC: 台积电，是台湾的一家半导体制造公司，也是全球最大的代工厂之一。
  7. know-how: 专业知识、技术秘诀，指的是某个行业或领域内的实践经验、技能和技术知识。
  8. boffins: 科学家、专家，是对科研人员的俚语称呼。
  9. dwindle: 减少，缩小。
  10. “churning out”意为大量生产、连续不断地制造。例如：The factory has been churning out cars at a remarkable pace.（这家工厂一直以惊人的速度大量生产汽车。）
  11. “having trouble getting their hands on”是一个习语，意为遇到困难，难以获得或接触到某物。例如：The company is having trouble getting their hands on the raw materials they need.（这家公司在获取所需原材料时遇到了困难。）
The triple shortage—of data, hardware and expertise—has been a hurdle forChina. Whether it will hold Chinese AI ambitions back much longer is anothermatter.
Take data. In February local authorities in Beijing, where nearly a third ofChina’s AI firms are located, promised to release data from 115 state-affiliated organisations, giving model-builders 15,880 data sets to play with.The central government has previously signalled it wants to dismantle Chineseapps’ walled gardens, potentially liberating more data, says Kayla Blomquist,an American former diplomat in China now at Oxford University. The latestmodels are also able to transfer their machine learnings from one language toanother. OpenAI says that GPT-4 performs remarkably well on tasks in Chinesedespite scarce Chinese source material in its training data. Baidu’s ERNIE wastrained on lots of English-language data, notes Jeffrey Ding of GeorgeWashington University.
In hardware, too, China is finding workarounds. The Financial Times reportedin March that SenseTime, which is blacklisted by America, was using middlemento skirt the export controls. Some Chinese AI firms are harnessing Nvidia’sprocessors through cloud servers in other countries. Alternatively, they canbuy more of Nvidia’s less advanced wares—to keep serving the vast Chinesemarket, Nvidia has designed sanctions-compliant ones that are between 10% and30% slower than top-of-the-range kit. These end up being costlier for theChinese customers per unit of processing power. But they do the job.
数据、硬件和专业知识的三重短缺一直是中国发展人工智能面临的障碍。它是否会继续阻碍中国的人工智能雄心壮志，则是另外一个问题。
就数据而言，北京市几乎三分之一的中国人工智能公司于2月承诺公开来自115个国有机构的数据，使得模型构建者可以使用15880组数据进行实验。美国前驻华外交官Kayla Blomquist现在在牛津大学任教，她表示，中央政府此前已经表明希望拆除中国应用程序的围墙花园，从而有可能释放更多数据。最新的模型还可以将其机器学习从一种语言转移到另一种语言。OpenAI表示，尽管训练数据中稀缺中文来源材料，但GPT-4在中文任务上表现出色。乔治·华盛顿大学的Jeffrey Ding指出，百度的ERNIE是通过大量的英文数据进行训练的。
在硬件方面，中国也正在寻找解决方法。据《金融时报》报道，被美国列入黑名单的商汤科技正在利用中间商规避出口管制。一些中国人工智能公司通过其他国家的云服务器利用Nvidia的处理器。或者，他们可以购买更多的Nvidia较低级别的产品——为了继续服务庞大的中国市场，Nvidia设计了符合制裁要求的产品，比顶尖设备慢10%至30%。这些产品的每个处理能力单位成本更高，但它们能胜任工作。
  1. triple shortage: 三重短缺，指的是在数据、硬件和专业知识等方面出现的三重不足的情况。
  2. hurdle: 障碍，指阻碍进展或成功的事物。
  3. model-builders: 模型构建者，指的是负责开发、建立和调整人工智能模型的专业人士。
  4. walled gardens: 围墙花园，指应用程序中的信息孤岛，限制了信息共享和互通的程度。
  5. machine learning: 机器学习，是一种通过对数据进行分析和学习来改进计算机算法性能的技术。
  6. Nvidia: 美国芯片设计公司，主要生产面向游戏、人工智能和数据中心等领域的高性能处理器和显卡。
  7. sanctions-compliant: 符合制裁要求的，指符合相关制裁措施的规定要求。
  8. top-of-the-range kit: 最顶级的设备，指最先进、最高端的设备。
  9. SenseTime: 商汤科技，是中国一家人工智能公司，主要从事计算机视觉和深度学习等领域的研究和开发。
  10. cloud servers: 云服务器，是指通过互联网提供计算、存储、网络和应用程序等服务的虚拟化资源。
  11. unit of processing power: 处理能力单位，是指计算机或其他电子设备处理数据的速度和效率的量度单位。
  12. end up: 最终成为，意味着经过一系列的过程或变化后得出某个结论或结果。例如：I didn’t want to go out, but I ended up going anyway.（我本不想出去，但我最终还是去了。）
  13. “workaround”是一个名词，意为解决困难或问题的方法，通常是通过绕过某些限制或规定来实现。例如：Because the software was incompatible with my computer, I had to find a workaround to get it to work.（由于这个软件与我的电脑不兼容，我不得不找到一种解决方法来使它工作。）
  14. “using middlemen to skirt the export controls”意为利用中间商规避出口管制。其中，”middlemen”指的是中间商或中间人，即在交易双方之间进行协调和联系的代理人，而”skirt”则是绕开或避开的意思。这句话描述了商汤科技通过利用中间人的方式规避出口管制的情况。
  15. “harnessing” 是一个动词，意为驾驭、利用或控制某物以达到特定目的。在这个上下文中，指的是中国一些人工智能公司通过云服务器等方式来利用 Nvidia 的处理器。例如：The company is harnessing new technologies to create better products.（该公司正在利用新技术创造更好的产品。）
China could partly alleviate the dearth of chips—and of brain power—with thehelp of “open-source” models. Such models’ inner workings can be downloaded byanyone and fine-tuned to a specific task. Those include the numbers, called“weights”, which define the structure of the model and which are derived fromcostly training runs. Researchers at Stanford used the weights from LLaMA,Meta’s foundation model, to build one called Alpaca for less than $600,compared with perhaps $100m for training something like GPT-4. Alpaca performsjust as well as the original version of ChatGPT on some tasks.
Chinese AI labs could similarly avail themselves of open-source models, whichembody the collective wisdom of international research teams. Matt Sheehan ofthe Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, another think-tank, says thatChina has form in being a “fast follower”—its labs have absorbed advances fromabroad and rapidly incorporated them into their own models, often with flushstate resources. A prominent Silicon Valley venture capitalist is more blunt,calling open-source models a gift to the*.
Such considerations make it hard to imagine that either America or China couldbuild an unbridgeable lead in AI modelling. Each may well end up with AIs ofsimilar ability, even if it costs China over the odds in the face of Americansanctions. But if the race of the model-builders is a dead heat, America hasone thing going for it that may make it the big AI winner—its ability tospread cutting-edge innovation throughout the economy. 
中国可以在“开源”模型的帮助下部分缓解芯片和人才短缺的问题。这些模型的内部结构可以被任何人下载并调整到特定任务上使用。这包括称为“权值”的数字，这些数字定义了模型的结构，并来自昂贵的训练运行。斯坦福大学的研究人员利用Meta公司的基础模型LLaMA的权重，仅花费不到600美元就建立了一个名为Alpaca的模型，相比之下GPT-4的培训成本可能达到1亿美元左右。Alpaca在某些任务上与ChatGPT的原始版本表现一样好。
中国的人工智能实验室也可以通过采用开源模型来获益，这些模型体现了国际研究团队的集体智慧。卡内基国际和平基金会的另一位智库专家Matt Sheehan表示，中国在成为“快速跟随者”方面有着丰富的经验，其实验室已经吸收了国外的先进技术，并迅速将其纳入自己的模型中，通常是在政府的资金支持下进行。一位知名的硅谷风险投资家更直言不讳地表示，开源模型是送给*的礼物。
这些因素使得很难想象美国或中国在人工智能建模上可以建立一个无法跨越的领先优势。即使面对美国的制裁，中国也可能会花费过多成本，最终拥有与美国相似的人工智能能力。但如果模型构建者的竞赛是胶着状态，那么美国有一件事情让它成为大人物——即将尖端创新技术传播到经济中。
  1. dearth: 缺乏，指某物的数量不足或缺少。
  2. open-source: 开源，指软件或硬件的设计和开发遵循的一种开放式协作模式，在此模式下，源代码对于所有人都是公开可见且可以自由使用、修改和分发的。
  3. inner workings: 内部运作机制，指所述物件的内部结构和工作原理。
  4. fine-tuned: 微调，指通过调整参数或细节等进行微小但重要的改进，以实现更好的结果或性能。
  5. flush state resources: 丰富的国家资源，指政府拥有大量财政、技术和其他资源来支持人工智能研究和开发。
  6. diffusion: 扩散，指技术或知识等从一个领域或组织向另一个领域或组织的传播过程。
  7. PhDs: 哲学博士学位，是一种高等教育学位，通常在完成一定的研究项目和论文后被授予。
  8. unbridgeable: 无法跨越的，指某事物在程度或程度上不能被弥合或克服。
  9. modelling: 建模，指通过使用数据和算法来创建人工智能模型以实现特定任务的过程。
  10. cutting-edge: 尖端的，指最新、最先进或最先进的技术或方法。
  11. dead heat: 平局，指某个竞赛或争夺中两方表现相当，无法分出胜负的状态。
  12. “Each may well end up with AIs of similar ability, even if it costs China over the odds in the face of American sanctions.”这句话的意思是，尽管在面对美国的制裁时，中国可能需要投入更多的资源和成本，但两国最终都有可能拥有类似能力的人工智能。其中，“over the odds”意为过高的代价或不必要的成本。该句话表达了即使中国需要花费更高的代价来发展人工智能，在技术上仍然可以与美国保持相似的水平。在这个句子中，”well”的作用是加强说话者对某种情况的判断或预测。它表示说话者认为某种情况非常可能发生，甚至可以说是几乎确定的。
Its fintech platforms, 5G telecoms and high-speed rail are allworld-class. Still, those successes may be the exception, not the rule, saysMr Ding. Particularly, China has done less well in deploying cloud computingand business software—both complementary to AI.
And though American export controls may not derail all Chinese model-building,they constrain China’s tech industry more broadly, thereby slowing theadoption of new technology. Moreover, Chinese businesses as a whole, andespecially small and medium-sized ones, are short of technologists who act asconduits for technological diffusion. Swathes of the economy are dominated bystate-owned firms, which tend to be stodgy and change-averse. Parts of it aredodgy. China’s “Big Fund” for chips, which raised $50bn in 2014 with a view tobacking domestic semiconductor firms, has been mired in scandals. Many of thethousands of new AI startups are AI in name only, slapping on the label to geta slice of the lavish subsidies doled out by the state to the favouredindustry.
As a consequence, China’s private sector may struggle to take full advantageof generative AI, especially if the * imposes strict rules toprevent chatbots from saying something its censors dislike. The handicapswould come on top of Mr *’s broader suborning of private enterprise,including a two-and-a-half-year crackdown on China’s tech industry.
Although the anti-tech campaign has officially ended, it has left deep scars,not least in the AI business. Last year private investments in Chinese AIstartups amounted to $13.5bn, less than one-third of the sum that flowed totheir American rivals. In the first four months of 2023 the funding gapappears only to have widened, according to PitchBook, a data provider. Whetheror not generative AI proves revolutionary, the free market has placed its beton who will make the most of it. ■
中国金融科技平台、5G电信和高速铁路等都是世界级的。不过，丁先生表示，这些成功或许只是例外而非常态。特别是，在部署云计算和企业软件方面，中国做得不如人意——这两者都是人工智能的重要补充。
尽管美国的出口管制可能不会破坏中国所有的模型构建，但它们会更广泛地限制中国的科技行业，从而减缓新技术的采纳。此外，整个中国的企业，特别是中小企业，缺乏作为技术传播渠道的技术人才。经济的大部分领域被国有企业所主导，它们往往保守且不喜变革。其中一些领域还存在问题。中国为芯片设立的“大基金”曾于2014年筹集了500亿美元，旨在支持国内半导体企业，但后来陷入丑闻。成千上万的新型人工智能初创公司仅仅打上人工智能的标签以获取政府给予优惠产业的慷慨补贴。
因此，中国的私营部门可能难以充分利用生成式人工智能，特别是如果*实施严格的规定以防止聊天机器人说出监管者不喜欢的话。这些劣势将叠加在中国政府对私营企业的更广泛的扰动之上，包括对中国科技行业进行为期两年半的打压。虽然反科技运动已正式结束，但它留下了深深的伤痕，尤其是在人工智能领域。去年，投资于中国人工智能初创公司的私人投资金额仅为135亿美元，不到流向美国竞争对手的三分之一。根据数据提供商PitchBook的数据，2023年前四个月的资金差距似乎只会进一步扩大。无论生成式人工智能是否被证明具有革命性，自由市场已经押注谁将最好地利用它。
  1. fintech: 金融科技，指在金融服务领域应用先进技术的公司和产品。
  2. high-speed rail: 高速铁路，指设计时速为250公里以上的铁路运输系统。
  3. cloud computing: 云计算，是一种通过网络提供按需、可扩展的计算资源（如服务器、存储和应用程序）的模式。
  4. semiconductor: 半导体，是指在一些材料中电阻率和导电率介于导体和绝缘体之间的材料。
  5. subsidies: 补贴，是由政府或其他机构向特定行业或企业提供的资金或物质上的支持。
  6. suborning：诱使，促使。
  7. crackdown: 严厉打击，是指政府对某种不良行为采取强有力的措施以扫清障碍或打击违法行为。
  8. generative AI: 生成型AI，是指可以自主生成类似于人类创造的输出结果的AI技术。
  9. censors：审查员，指对言论、出版物等进行审核和审查的人员或机构。
  10. funding gap：资金差距，指在某个领域或行业中，不同企业或组织之间获得资金的数量或质量上存在的差异。
  11. PitchBook：PitchBook是全球领先的数据提供商，专注于风险投资、私募股权和M&A交易等领域，为用户提供业内权威数据和分析服务。
  12. anti-tech campaign: 技术反弹，是指政府通过一系列措施限制或打压某些技术行业的发展。在本文中，该词指代中国政府对科技产业的打击和限制。
  13. private investments: 私人投资，是指由个人或企业自主决定向特定领域或企业提供资金支持的行为。
  14. free market: 自由市场，是指市场经济中，供求关系由市场自身调节而无需政府干预的状态。
  15. revolutionary: 革命性的，指某种技术或思想能够彻底改变现有的社会、经济或科技模式。
  16. place one’s bet on: 押注于，是指将自己的期望或赌注放在某种结果或人身上，希望获得成功或利益。
  17. mired in scandals: 陷入丑闻，指某个机构或行业因为某些不良事件或行为而受到负面影响或损失。

entry.title: The world in brief 2023-05-14
entry.content:
The world in brief

Catch up quickly on the global stories that matter

Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, met Italy’s prime minister,Giorgia Meloni, and president, Sergio Mattarella, in Rome. Despite somemembers of her right-wing coalition having expressed pro-Kremlin views—mostnotably Matteo Salvini, the deputy prime minister—Ms Meloni has pledged hergovernment’s support for the war-torn country. Mr Zelensky also met PopeFrancis at the Vatican, and is expected to travel next to Germany. The Germangovernment announced €2.7bn ($2.95bn) of military aid for Ukraine ahead of hisarrival.

Voting began in Thailand’s general election, with a good chance thatvoters will eject the prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha, a former general whoseized power in a coup in 2014. The Pheu Thai party is expected to romp tovictory. It is led by Paetongtarn Shinawatra, the daughter of ThaksinShinawatra, a prime minister the army overthrew in 2006. The militaryestablishment may not cede power graciously.

Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Turkey’s leader, accused opposition parties ofcollaborating with America in an effort to oust him from power in thepresidential election on Sunday. Several polls have suggested that Mr Erdoganis behind the umbrella opposition candidate, Kemal Kilicdaroglu. MrKilicdaroglu would need to win more than 50% of the vote to win outright andstop the contest going to a run-off later this month.

America and the EU will co-ordinate their controls on exportingsemiconductors and other critical technology to China, according to a draftstatement seen by Reuters. They are also expected to announce joint measuresto address Chinese economic coercion at a meeting in Sweden at the end of May.The report comes amid concerns, particularly among American officials, thatapproaches to China on each side of the Atlantic may diverge.

Congress, India’s main opposition party, won an emphatic victory inelections in the southern state of Karnataka, defeating the ruling BharatiyaJanata Party. The vote is the first of five crucial state elections this yearthat will set the tone for national parliamentary elections, due by April2024. Rahul Gandhi, Congress’s leader, lost his parliamentary seat this yearhaving been convicted of defamation.

Israel and Islamic Jihad, a militant group in Palestine , agreed to aceasefire to end five days of fighting in which 33 people died. The violenceerupted when Israel killed three Islamist commanders it accused of planningattacks on their soil, resulting in the worst cross-border fire since a 10-daywar in 2021. Many are sceptical that the latest truce, brokered by Egypt,addresses the underlying issues in the conflict.

Sweden won the Eurovision Song Contest , a staggeringly popularcheesefest. Loreen sang the winning entry, “Tattoo”, the second time she hastriumphed at the competition. Sweden has now prevailed in the annual contest arecord-equalling seven times. Its first success came in 1974 with a then-obscure band named ABBA.

Word of the week: sledging, what cricketers call trash talking. Read thefull story.

Photo:Reuters

All eyes on Turkey’s elections

Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Turkey’s strongman, may have hoped to split theopposition vote in his country’s presidential elections on Sunday. But anyprospect of doing so seemed to fade on Thursday when Muharrem Ince, a formerRepublican People’s Party (CHP) politician and potential spoiler candidate,dropped out.

That was good news for the CHP’s leader, Kemal Kilicdaroglu, who is beingfielded as the opposition’s umbrella candidate. At least three recent pollsgive him more than 49% of the vote, and Mr Erdogan between 44% and 47% (othercandidates, including Mr Ince, make up the rest). Mr Kilicdaroglu willprobably inherit most of Mr Ince’s support—thought to be around 2%. That couldhelp swing him over the 50% mark needed to win outright. Failing that,opposition supporters fear that a runoff would give Mr Erdogan time to make upground by stoking more division. It will go down to the wire.

Photo:Getty Images

Peace between Armenia and Azerbaijan remains elusive

On Sunday Armenia’s prime minister, Nikol Pashinyan, and Azerbaijan’spresident, Ilham Aliyev, will meet in Brussels to try to resolve the festeringdispute over Nagorno-Karabakh, a region that has triggered two wars in thepast 30 years. The second ended in late 2020, when Azerbaijan recaptured fromArmenian forces parts of the enclave—which is populated mostly by Armeniansbut is formally part of Azerbaijan—as well as adjacent regions.

Violence has intermittently flared since. On Thursday, clashes betweenAzerbaijani and Armenian troops near Sotk, an Armenian village around 100kmwest of Nagorno-Karabakh, left one soldier dead and four others injured.

The EU-brokered talks, mediated by Charles Michel, president of the EuropeanCouncil, have made some headway in previous rounds. Still, a comprehensivepeace deal seems far off. Mr Pashinyan recently told members of his cabinetthat a draft agreement was “at a very preliminary stage”. He and Mr Aliyev areexpected to meet again in Moldova next month.

Photo:Getty Images

Adding smells to virtual reality

“Smells are surer than sounds or sights/ To make your heart-strings crack”,wrote Rudyard Kipling, an English poet. The entertainment industry has takennote. In some cinemas in the 1960s “Smell-O-Vision” pumped 30 different odoursout from under the seats at appropriate plot points. But viewers complainedabout the whiffs being delayed, too faint or else irritatingly persistent. Theidea was shelved.

Perhaps virtual reality will have more success with olfactory innovation.Researchers from China and Hong Kong have invented two different wearable“olfaction interfaces”, as described in a new paper in NatureCommunications. One device is plaster-sized and affixed under the nose; theother is worn as a face mask. Both systems rely on tiny tiles containingparaffin wax that, when heated, release smells, such as green tea or mint.

Others smell a business opportunity. OVR, a startup in Vermont, has a headsetwhich uses a system of refillable liquid cartridges. Whether the smelly VRwill do better than funky films remains to be seen.

Photo:AFP

Weekend profile: Martin Griffiths, UN mediator

Talks to resolve the devastating conflict in Sudan began in Saudi Arabia’scoastal city of Jeddah last weekend. But so far representatives of the twowarring factions—the army led by General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan and the RapidSupport Forces led by the warlord Muhammad Hamdan Dagalo—as well as Americanand Saudi diplomats, have struggled for a breakthrough. They have only managedto sign a declaration committing to protect civilians. The intense fighting,which has left over 600 dead and thousands more injured since April 15th,could well continue. It is familiarly unpromising territory for the otherattendee at the talks, Martin Griffiths, the UN’s leading troubleshooter andperhaps the world’s most experienced mediator.

The slightly crumpled, silver-haired 71-year-old Welshman is a familiarpresence at the world’s hotspots. If Sudan wasn’t tough enough, after a fewdays in Jeddah Mr Griffiths jetted off to Turkey to sit down with theUkrainians and Russians to negotiate an extension of the Black Sea grain deal(it expires on May 18th). He is now the UN’s top humanitarian official, a jobhe took in 2021 after three years as the secretary-general’s special envoy towar-torn Yemen.

Mr Griffiths trained as a barrister and later worked for NGOs, such as ActionAid, and for the British Foreign Office. It is this unusual combination thathas made him effective: he deploys the skills of a hard-nosed politicaloperator in the humanitarian causes of famine relief or peace-building, and iscomfortable in the cloak-and-dagger world of back channels and intelligencework that is often required for conflict resolution. In 1999 he co-founded theCentre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), a discrete mediation outfit. It becamea model for an entire industry, outsourcing conflict mediation to privateorganisations rather than governments. With HD, Mr Griffiths was closelyinvolved in peace talks in the Indonesian province of Aceh, and supported KofiAnnan’s successful mediation in Kenya after post-election violence in 2008threatened to rip the country apart.

In Sudan, his main job is to negotiate a “humanitarian pause”, a temporarycessation of hostilities to allow food and aid to be distributed to animmiserated population. But the hope is that such ceasefire agreements canlead to political talks. Mr Griffith’s job in Yemen started brightly as hepersuaded the warring parties to allow access to a crucial port, but a wideragreement was never fully implemented. The world must hope that he has betterluck in Sudan.

Photo:Rex Shutterstock

An ambitious plan for amphibious cities

What do Lagos, in Nigeria, and Rotterdam, in the Netherlands, have in common?Both cities are low-lying and near the sea. That makes them vulnerable toextreme weather and rising sea levels, which are accelerated by climatechange. The cities are also home to communities that live on their waterways.Lagosians’ “water cities” have long inspired Kunle Adeyemi, a Nigerianarchitect based in Amsterdam, who believes aquatic settlements can easepressures on cramped, coastal megacities. The structures can also potentiallyhelp urban areas adapt to climate change by offering flood-proof living space.

This idea underpins his new exhibition, “Water Cities Rotterdam. By KunleAdeyemi”, which opens on Sunday at the Nieuwe Instituut, a design museum inthe Dutch city. The centrepiece is a seven-metre-high wooden pavilion thatwill float on the ponds outside the museum building. Water-based living is notnew: indigenous people around the world have existed on lakes and lagoons forcenturies. But the concept may be about to get a 21st-century update.

Weekly crossword

Our crossword has two sets of clues, one for seasoned cruciverbalists and theother for less experienced solvers. Both give the same answers, all of whichfeature in articles in this week’s edition of The Economist.

Email all four answers, along with your home city and country, by 9am GMT onMonday to crossword@economist.com. We will pick randomly from those with theright answers and crown three winners in next week’s edition.

Cryptic clues

1 down With God, luck and lira, I could become president (12)

1 across Knock back tot before hijack (6)

2 across Flying machine, done right, explodes (5)

3 across In huff I zipped to gallery (6)

Factual clues

1 down Candidate hoping to replace Recep Tayyip Erdogan (12)

1 across What Mexican gangs do to some migrants (6)

2 across Civilian device weaponised by Ukrainians (5)

3 across Italian gallery sending art out on the road (6)

The winners of this week’s quiz

Thank you to everyone who took part in this week’s quiz. The winners, chosenat random, were:

Erik Feng , Austin, Texas, United States

Nagia El Harai , Cairo, Egypt

Kobchai Kingchatchaval , Bangkok, Thailand

They all gave the correct answers of Victor Borge, Quebec, November criminals,Nile delta and Zulus. The theme is terms in the NATO phonetic alphabet:Victor, Quebec, November, delta and Zulu.

The questions were:

Monday: Which pianist, who performed a routine called “phoneticpunctuation”, was known as the “clown prince of Denmark”?
Tuesday: Which is Canada’s largest province by area?
Wednesday: What pejorative term was given to the German politicians whosigned the armistice at the end of the first world war?
Thursday: Which historically important geographic formation spans fromAlexandria in the west to Port Said in the east?
Friday: Jacob Zuma and Mangosuthu Buthelezi are members of which SouthAfrican ethnic group?

Walking is a virtue, tourism is a deadly sin.

Bruce Chatwin

entry.title: Article-What does a leaked Google memo reveal about the future of AI?-2023-05-13
entry.content:
Leaders | A stochastic parrot in every pot
What does a leaked Google memo reveal about the future of AI?
Open-source AI is booming. That makes it less likely that a handful of firms will control the technology
May 11th 2023
THEY HAVE changed the world by writing software. But techy types are alsoknown for composing lengthy memos in prose, the most famous of which havemarked turning points in computing. Think of Bill Gates’s “Internet tidalwave” memo of 1995, which reoriented Microsoft towards the web; or JeffBezos’s “API mandate” memo of 2002, which opened up Amazon’s digitalinfrastructure, paving the way for modern cloud computing. Now techies areabuzz about another memo, this time leaked from within Google, titled “We haveno moat”. Its unknown author details the astonishing progress being made inartificial intelligence (AI)—and challenges some long-held assumptions aboutthe balance of power in this fast-moving industry.
AI burst into the public consciousness with the launch in late 2022 ofChatGPT, a chatbot powered by a “large language model” (LLM) made by OpenAI, astartup closely linked to Microsoft. Its success prompted Google and othertech firms to release their own LLM-powered chatbots. Such systems cangenerate text and hold realistic conversations because they have been trainedusing trillions of words taken from the internet. Training a large LLM takesmonths and costs tens of millions of dollars. This led to concerns that AIwould be dominated by a few deep-pocketed firms.
But that assumption is wrong, says the Google memo. It notes that researchersin the open-source community, using free, online resources, are now achievingresults comparable to the biggest proprietary models. It turns out that LLMscan be “fine-tuned” using a technique called low-rank adaptation, or LoRa.This allows an existing LLM to be optimised for a particular task far morequickly and cheaply than training an LLM from scratch.
Activity in open-source AI exploded in March, when LLaMa, a model created byMeta, Facebook’s parent, was leaked online. Although it is smaller than thelargest LLMs (its smallest version has 7bn parameters, compared with 540bn forGoogle’s PaLM) it was quickly fine-tuned to produce results comparable to theoriginal version of ChatGPT on some tasks. As open-source researchers built oneach other’s work with LLaMa, “a tremendous outpouring of innovationfollowed,” the memo’s author writes.
This could have seismic implications for the industry’s future. “The barrierto entry for training and experimentation has dropped from the total output ofa major research organisation to one person, an evening, and a beefy laptop,”the Google memo claims. An LLM can now be fine-tuned for $100 in a few hours.With its fast-moving, collaborative and low-cost model, “open-source has somesignificant advantages that we cannot replicate.” Hence the memo’s title: thismay mean Google has no defensive “moat” against open-source competitors. Nor,for that matter, does OpenAI.
Not everyone agrees with this thesis. It is true that the internet runs onopen-source software. But people use paid-for, proprietary software, fromAdobe Photoshop to Microsoft Windows, as well. AI may find a similar balance.Moreover, benchmarking AI systems is notoriously hard. Yet even if the memo ispartly right, the implication is that access to AI technology will be far moredemocratised than seemed possible even a year ago. Powerful LLMs can be run ona laptop; anyone who wants to can now fine-tune their own AI.
This has both positive and negative implications. On the plus side, it makesmonopolistic control of AI by a handful of companies far less likely. It willmake access to AI much cheaper, accelerate innovation across the field andmake it easier for researchers to analyse the behaviour of AI systems (theiraccess to proprietary models was limited), boosting transparency and safety.But easier access to AI also means bad actors will be able to fine-tunesystems for nefarious purposes, such as generating disinformation. It meansWestern attempts to prevent hostile regimes from gaining access to powerful AItechnology will fail. And it makes AI harder to regulate, because the genie isout of the bottle.
Whether Google and its ilk really have lost their moat in AI will soon becomeapparent. But as with those previous memos, this feels like another turningpoint for computing. ■

entry.title: The world in brief 2023-05-13
entry.content:
The world in brief

Catch up quickly on the global stories that matter

Ukraine said it recaptured territory in Bakhmut , potentiallysignalling a change in momentum in the battle for the eastern town, which hasgrinded on for more than nine months. A Ukrainian military spokesperson saidthat Russian troops had been pushed back one and a half kilometres in the pastday. Russia’s defence ministry said it had pulled away for strategic reasons.But Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the Wagner Group, a Russian mercenaryoutfit, said Russian units were “running away”.

Elon Musk named Linda Yaccarino, the advertising chief at NBC Universal,as Twitter’s new chief executive. Mr Musk—a billionaire who reluctantlyacquired Twitter for $44bn in October—resigned as chief executive on Thursday.He has been under pressure from shareholders in Tesla, of which he is alsoCEO, to refocus on the company. The electric-vehicle company’s stock jumped 2%on the appointment news.

The number of migrants crossing to Europe through the centralMediterranean has quadrupled compared with last year, according to Frontex.The EU’s borders agency reported 28,000 arrivals by the sea route—whichaccounts for more than half of irregular crossings—in the first quarter of2023. The UN called it the deadliest period since 2017.

Vladimir Putin , Russia’s president, agreed to strengthen ties withCyril Ramaphosa , his South African counterpart, according to the Kremlin.In a call between the leaders Mr Putin also said he had never refused the“diplomatic track” to resolving the war in Ukraine and voiced support forinvolving African leaders in peace negotiations. On Thursday America accusedSouth Africa of supplying weapons to Russia.

Imran Khan , a former prime minister of Pakistan , was granted a two-week bail by the Islamabad High Court, a day after the Supreme Court deemedhis arrest unlawful. Mr Khan was detained on Tuesday by the country’s anti-graft agency on corruption charges. He denies any wrongdoing. The dramaticdetention triggered protests across the country, in which at least 11 peoplewere killed and nearly 2,000 arrested.

After a week of talks, Sudan’s warring factions failed to agree to aceasefire, but promised to protect civilians. Fighting between Sudan’s armyand the Rapid Support Forces, a paramilitary unit, has killed more than 750people over the past month. Both sides signed a declaration saying they wouldwork towards a ceasefire in further discussions.

Justin Tkatchenko, Papua New Guinea’s foreign minister, resigned after thecost and size of his country’s delegation to King Charles III’s coronationsparked public outrage. A 30-person delegation travelled to London for thebash, each of whom was given a 50,000 kina ($14,000) allowance. Although aresource-rich country, almost 40% of PNG’s population lives in poverty,according to the World Bank.

Fact of the day: $500bn, the amount that America’s banks have inunrealised losses on their securities portfolios. Read the full story.

Photo:Getty Images

Sánchez talks migration with Biden

On Friday Pedro Sánchez, Spain’s Socialist prime minister, will meet PresidentJoe Biden for a propitiously timed meeting at the White House. Anticipating asurge of migrants across its southern border, America wants Spain to help easethe burden.

On May 4th America and Spain, along with Canada, vowed to strengthen co-operation on migration, especially from Central and South America. The threecountries want more legal “circular” migration: for people to come, work andthen leave. To do so they aim to set up centres in countries of origin, suchas Colombia and Honduras, that will help would-be migrants find legal avenuesout. The hope is that this will reduce the numbers making illegal crossings.

The timing of the meeting also suits Mr Sánchez, who faces regional electionson May 28th and national ones later in the year. He will relish theopportunity to discuss issues such as Ukraine with Mr Biden, and so to appearstatesmanlike on the global stage.

Photo:Rex Shutterstock

Britain’s economy in the doldrums

For a year Britain’s economy—like much of Europe’s—has been becalmed. Figurespublished on Friday showed that GDP grew by just 0.1% in the first quarter of2023. The economy was still 0.5% smaller than in the last full quarter beforethe covid-19 pandemic.

But the outlook seems a little brighter. The Bank of England said on Thursdaythat it no longer expects a recession. Consumers and businesses are becomingmore confident. Inflation, 10.1% in the year to March, has been a drag onpeople’s spending power, but should fall sharply when the leap in energyprices after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine drops out of the annual calculation.Yet with the rate far above the bank’s target of 2% and the labour marketstill tight, the bank is taking no chances. On Thursday it raised itsbenchmark interest rate by another quarter of a percentage point, to 4.5%—andmore increases look likely.

Photo:Getty Images

Toshiba’s cautious path to private ownership

On Friday Toshiba forecast weak earnings in the next year: operating profit isexpected to be ¥110bn ($816m), well below analysts’ expectations. Still, yearsof corporate chaos may be coming to an end.

The Japanese conglomerate’s troubles began with an accounting scandal in 2015.It nearly went bankrupt two years later, surviving by selling off a valuablebusiness and issuing $5.4bn of shares. A buyout offer in 2021 from CVC CapitalPartners, a private-equity firm, raised the idea of taking the 147-year-oldcompany off the publicly traded market. But Japan’s government was unsettledby the prospect of foreign ownership, given Toshiba’s interests in strategicindustries such as nuclear energy and semiconductors. That deal fell through,and infighting between shareholders and management ensued.

In March Toshiba’s board approved a different $15bn deal from Japan IndustrialPartners, a domestic consortium, which offered ¥4,620 per share, a 10%premium. On Friday the company confirmed that it is working with JIP toswiftly complete the transaction.

Photo:Getty Images

Turbulent times at SocGen

On Friday Société Générale, a big French bank, presented better-than-anticipated results for the first quarter. While its retail business sagged,net income rose by 5.7%, from €821m ($898m) in the same period last year to€868m.

The news is welcome at a challenging time for the bank . In February itreported a 64% drop in annual profits for 2022, owing in large part to a$3.3bn loss caused by the sale of its Russian business after the invasion ofUkraine, as well as higher provisions for bad loans. And in March Frenchpolice raided the offices of Société Générale, BNP Paribas and three otherbanks as part of an investigation related to so-called “cum-cum” trades, usedto evade taxes on dividend payments. Between them the five banks are nowfacing fines of more than €1bn.

After 15 years at the helm Frédéric Oudea, the bank’s chief executive, willstep down at its annual general meeting on May 23rd. Notwithstanding Friday’sboost, his successor, Slawomir Krupa, will have his work cut out.

Photo:eyevine

Two long-lost artworks back on display

How could eight vibrant Art Deco paintings, each more than eight feet tall,disappear? That was the 50-year mystery surrounding a series of works byWinold Reiss, a renowned modernist artist. Painted in 1938 to decorate arestaurant in the Empire State Building, the works were lost during arenovation in the 1960s.

Reiss, who emigrated from Germany to New York in 1913, channelled his adoptedcity’s energy and optimism into his art. That optimism sustained art loverswho refused to believe that these works had been destroyed. Earlier this yeara gallery director spotted a pair for sale online. The Reiss familyauthenticated them.

The two rediscovered works go on display from Friday at the TEFAF art fair inNew York. “Animation” depicts a nude woman in a tropical setting fending off aleopard; “Temptation” shows an Eve-like figure with a snake. The search forthe remaining six—including the appropriately titled “Anticipation”—continues.

Daily quiz

Our baristas will serve you a new question each day this week. On Friday yourchallenge is to give us all five answers and, as important, tell us theconnecting theme. Email your responses (and include mention of your home cityand country) by 1700 GMT on Friday to QuizEspresso@economist.com. We’ll pickrandomly from those with the right answers and crown three winners onSaturday.

Friday: Jacob Zuma and Mangosuthu Buthelezi are members of which SouthAfrican ethnic group?

Thursday: Which historically important geographic formation spans fromAlexandria in the west to Port Said in the east?

The winners of last week’s crossword

Thank you to everyone who took part in our weekly crossword, published in theweekend edition of Espresso. The winners, chosen at random, were:

Denis Bradu , Chisinau, Moldova
Pat Rapp , Brooklyn, America
Hiroyuki Sakurai , Tokyo, Japan

They all gave the correct answers of King Charles, Kansas, Hague and strike.Check back tomorrow for this week’s crossword.

Life is 10% what you make of it, and 90% how you take it.

Irving Berlin

entry.title: The world in brief 2023-05-12
entry.content:
The world in brief

Catch up quickly on the global stories that matter

Hundreds of migrants lined up at America’s border with Mexico as Title42 expired. The pandemic-era provision, which allows officials to quicklyturn away migrants at the border, ended on Thursday night. America’s secretaryof homeland security, Alejandro Mayorkas, stressed that the country’s borderswere “not open”. Some cities in Texas have already declared a state ofemergency, seeking more federal resources to handle the expected surge.

数百名移民在与墨西哥接壤的美国边境排队等候，因为《第42条》已经失效。这项在疫情时期实施的规定允许官员迅速拒绝边境处的移民，于周四晚间到期。美国国土安全部部长阿莱杰罗·马约尔卡斯强调，该国的边境并未完全开放。德克萨斯州的一些城市已经宣布进入紧急状态，寻求更多联邦资源来应对预期的涌入（移民潮）。值得注意的是，“第42条”这个词组指的是特朗普政府在2020年3月发布的一项政策，旨在遏制疫情蔓延。该条款授权边境和移民执法官员，将可能传染新冠病毒的人迅速遣返或拘留，即使他们符合庇护条件。这是一项备受争议的规定，受到了联邦法院和移民权利组织的挑战。

句子主干为 “Hundreds of migrants lined up at America’s border”，其中 “America’s border with Mexico” 修饰了地点。”as Title 42 expired” 是时间状语从句，承接前文提到的”pandemic-era provision”，意思是这项规定已于周四晚过期。接着是一个插入语：”which allows officials to quickly turn away migrants at the border”，解释了Title 42的内容，说明这项规定允许官员在边境迅速拒绝移民进入。随后 “America’s secretary of homeland security, Alejandro Mayorkas, stressed that the country’s borders were ‘not open’”，强调美国的边境并未完全开放，暗示着政府对移民问题持谨慎态度。最后一句话 “Some cities in Texas have already declared a state of emergency, seeking more federal resources to handle the expected surge.” 引出了一个新的情况：德克萨斯州的一些城市已经宣布进入紧急状态，寻求更多联邦资源来应对预期的涌入（移民潮）。

值得注意的是，”Title 42” 这个词组是指特朗普政府在2020年3月颁发的一项政策，旨在遏制疫情蔓延。该条款授权边境和移民执法官员，将可能传染新冠病毒的人迅速遣返或拘留，即使他们符合庇护条件。这是一项极具争议的规定，受到了联邦法院和移民权利组织的挑战。

  1. “pandemic-era provision” - 这个短语用来描述特朗普政府在疫情时期制定的政策规定，非常贴切地反映了这个时代的特殊背景。

  2. “America’s secretary of homeland security, Alejandro Mayorkas, stressed that the country’s borders were ‘not open’” - 这句话的表述十分简洁明了，强调了美国政府对移民问题的态度，并且使用了形象生动的动词”stressed”来突出重点。

  3. “Some cities in Texas have already declared a state of emergency, seeking more federal resources to handle the expected surge.” - 这句话有很多值得欣赏的地方。首先，采用了并列结构，清晰地列出了两个情况：德克萨斯州的一些城市已经宣布进入紧急状态，和他们寻求联邦资源来应对预期的移民潮。其次，使用了高频词汇”state of emergency”来形容紧急状态，表达了危机感。最后，整句话的组成也非常流畅自然，读起来很顺畅。

After a week of talks, Sudan’s warring factions failed to agree to aceasefire, but promised to protect civilians. Fighting between Sudan’s armyand the Rapid Support Forces, a paramilitary unit, has killed more than 750people over the past month. Both sides signed a declaration saying they wouldwork towards a ceasefire in further discussions.

Russia’s defence ministry denied that Ukrainian troops had made abreakthrough in the battle for Bakhmut. Reports suggest that Ukraine hasrecaptured land outside the eastern town. A broader counter-offensive againstRussia is on hold, according to Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine’s president, untilforces receive more deliveries of promised military aid. Britain confirmedthat it has supplied Ukraine with long-range cruise missiles.

Imran Khan , a former prime minister of Pakistan , was granted a two-week bail by the Islamabad High Court, a day after the Supreme Court deemedhis arrest unlawful. Mr Khan was detained on Tuesday by the country’s anti-graft agency on corruption charges. He denies any wrongdoing. The dramaticdetention triggered protests across the country, in which at least 11 peoplewere killed and nearly 2,000 arrested.

Mike Lynch , the co-founder of Autonomy , a British software group,was extradited to America having lost an appeal in the High Court last month.The billionaire faces criminal charges of fraud related to the $11bn takeoverof the company by Hewlett-Packard in 2011. He denies wrongdoing. A judge inCalifornia ordered Mr Lynch to pay a $100m bail bond after his arrival onThursday.

The South African rand dropped to an all-time low, after America’sambassador to the country accused it of supplying weapons to Russia in aclandestine naval operation. The rand dropped 1.4% to R19.34 against thedollar, passing its previous low of 19.35 in April 2020. South Africa alsosuffered its worst power cuts on record this week, darkening the mood ofinvestors.

Astronomers uncovered more details about the largest cosmic explosion everobserved. AT2021lwx, as it has been called, was triggered by a vast cloud ofgas—more than a thousand times bigger than the sun—being absorbed into asupermassive black hole nearly 8bn light years away. The fireball was firstspotted in 2020 but its true scale has only recently been understood.

Fact of the day: $500bn, the amount that America’s banks have inunrealised losses on their securities portfolios. Read the full story.

Photo:Getty Images

Sánchez talks migration with Biden

On Friday Pedro Sánchez, Spain’s Socialist prime minister, will meet PresidentJoe Biden for a propitiously timed meeting at the White House. Anticipating asurge of migrants across its southern border, America wants Spain to help easethe burden.

On May 4th America and Spain, along with Canada, vowed to strengthen co-operation on migration, especially from Central and South America. The threecountries want more legal “circular” migration: for people to come, work andthen leave. To do so they aim to set up centres in countries of origin, suchas Colombia and Honduras, that will help would-be migrants find legal avenuesout. The hope is that this will reduce the numbers making illegal crossings.

The timing of the meeting also suits Mr Sánchez, who faces regional electionson May 28th and national ones later in the year. He will relish theopportunity to discuss issues such as Ukraine with Mr Biden, and so to appearstatesmanlike on the global stage.

Photo:Getty Images

Toshiba’s cautious path to private ownership

On Friday Toshiba forecast weak earnings in the next year: operating profit isexpected to be ¥110bn ($816m), well below analysts’ expectations. Still, yearsof corporate chaos may be coming to an end.

The Japanese conglomerate’s troubles began with an accounting scandal in 2015.It nearly went bankrupt two years later, surviving by selling off a valuablebusiness and issuing $5.4bn of shares. A buyout offer in 2021 from CVC CapitalPartners, a private-equity firm, raised the idea of taking the 147-year-oldcompany off the publicly traded market. But Japan’s government was unsettledby the prospect of foreign ownership, given Toshiba’s interests in strategicindustries such as nuclear energy and semiconductors. That deal fell through,and infighting between shareholders and management ensued.

In March Toshiba’s board approved a different $15bn deal from Japan IndustrialPartners, a domestic consortium, which offered ¥4,620 per share, a 10%premium. On Friday the company confirmed that it is working with JIP toswiftly complete the transaction.

Photo:Rex Shutterstock

Britain’s economy in the doldrums

For a year Britain’s economy—like much of Europe’s—has been becalmed. Figurespublished on Friday showed that GDP grew by just 0.1% in the first quarter of2023. The economy was still 0.5% smaller than in the last full quarter beforethe covid-19 pandemic.

But the outlook seems a little brighter. The Bank of England said on Thursdaythat it no longer expects a recession. Consumers and businesses are becomingmore confident. Inflation, 10.1% in the year to March, has been a drag onpeople’s spending power, but should fall sharply when the leap in energyprices after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine drops out of the annual calculation.Yet with the rate far above the bank’s target of 2% and the labour marketstill tight, the bank is taking no chances. On Thursday it raised itsbenchmark interest rate by another quarter of a percentage point, to 4.5%—andmore increases look likely.

Photo:Getty Images

Turbulent times at SocGen

On Friday Société Générale, a big French bank, presented better-than-anticipated results for the first quarter. While its retail business sagged,net income rose by 5.7%, from €821m ($898m) in the same period last year to€868m.

The news is welcome at a challenging time for the bank . In February itreported a 64% drop in annual profits for 2022, owing in large part to a$3.3bn loss caused by the sale of its Russian business after the invasion ofUkraine, as well as higher provisions for bad loans. And in March Frenchpolice raided the offices of Société Générale, BNP Paribas and three otherbanks as part of an investigation related to so-called “cum-cum” trades, usedto evade taxes on dividend payments. Between them the five banks are nowfacing fines of more than €1bn.

After 15 years at the helm Frédéric Oudea, the bank’s chief executive, willstep down at its annual general meeting on May 23rd. Notwithstanding Friday’sboost, his successor, Slawomir Krupa, will have his work cut out.

Photo:eyevine

Two long-lost artworks back on display

How could eight vibrant Art Deco paintings, each more than eight feet tall,disappear? That was the 50-year mystery surrounding a series of works byWinold Reiss, a renowned modernist artist. Painted in 1938 to decorate arestaurant in the Empire State Building, the works were lost during arenovation in the 1960s.

Reiss, who emigrated from Germany to New York in 1913, channelled his adoptedcity’s energy and optimism into his art. That optimism sustained art loverswho refused to believe that these works had been destroyed. Earlier this yeara gallery director spotted a pair for sale online. The Reiss familyauthenticated them.

The two rediscovered works go on display from Friday at the TEFAF art fair inNew York. “Animation” depicts a nude woman in a tropical setting fending off aleopard; “Temptation” shows an Eve-like figure with a snake. The search forthe remaining six—including the appropriately titled “Anticipation”—continues.

Daily quiz

Our baristas will serve you a new question each day this week. On Friday yourchallenge is to give us all five answers and, as important, tell us theconnecting theme. Email your responses (and include mention of your home cityand country) by 1700 GMT on Friday to QuizEspresso@economist.com. We’ll pickrandomly from those with the right answers and crown three winners onSaturday.

Friday: Jacob Zuma and Mangosuthu Buthelezi are members of which SouthAfrican ethnic group?

Thursday: Which historically important geographic formation spans fromAlexandria in the west to Port Said in the east?

The winners of last week’s crossword

Thank you to everyone who took part in our weekly crossword, published in theweekend edition of Espresso. The winners, chosen at random, were:

Denis Bradu , Chisinau, Moldova
Pat Rapp , Brooklyn, America
Hiroyuki Sakurai , Tokyo, Japan

They all gave the correct answers of King Charles, Kansas, Hague and strike.Check back tomorrow for this week’s crossword.

Life is 10% what you make of it, and 90% how you take it.

Irving Berlin

entry.title: 如何获取自动更新经济学人Espresso内容（墙内可用）
entry.content:
自动更新经济学人Espresso内容（墙内可用）网址1：https://github.com/arielherself/espresso网址2：https://arielherself.github.io/espresso-native

将economist.com改成te.arielherself.xyz即可【无需订阅、无广告】浏览经济学人网站所有内容。

例：https://te.arielherself.xyz/the-world-ahead/2022/11/21/ten-business-trends-for-2023-and-forecasts-for-15-industries

如遇音频按钮挡住正文的情况，请用AdGuard等广告拦截器将按钮标记为广告，即可。

网速如果太慢，建议开国际网
